metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of desert station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the desert station eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (100.9872° E, 42.1135° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 1054 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.7 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the type of eddy covariance was closed-path (CPEC200).
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: In oasis–desert ecosystems, data collection for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges is performed using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. This method involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data, along with auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in maintaining observational datasets in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Example.Answer: A challenge in maintaining observational datasets in arid and semiarid inland river basins includes ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in areas like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset available for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions of western China?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset available for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions of western China includes observations from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB), incorporating data from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations since 2012. This dataset includes flux observations, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters and is accessible from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is an eddy covariance system and how is it used in the context of data collection in arid and semi-arid regions?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to measure turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane in ecosystems. In arid and semi-arid regions, this system is crucial for understanding the exchanges between the land surface and the atmosphere, particularly in oasis–desert areas. It provides half-hourly flux data that helps in analyzing the balance of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange necessary for sustainable development.

Definition.Question: What are the primary challenges faced in collecting long-term observational data in arid inland river basins?
Definition.Answer: The primary challenges in collecting long-term observational data in arid inland river basins include ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road, making data collection and ecological monitoring difficult.

Definition.Question: What types of data are typically included in datasets from oasis–desert systems, and why are they important?
Definition.Answer: Datasets from oasis–desert systems typically include long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. This data is important for understanding the basic characteristics and interactions of oasis–desert ecosystems, which are crucial for ecological security, sustainable development, and achieving goals like carbon neutrality in these regions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers compare to traditional meteorological stations in terms of capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semiarid regions?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and scintillometers provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, whereas traditional meteorological stations generally provide hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period. Eddy covariance systems focus on fluxes like energy, water vapor, and carbon, while traditional stations focus on broader meteorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and gradients of air temperature and humidity.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing steps between using Eddypro software for eddy covariance data and typical data processing methods for hydrometeorological datasets?
Comparison.Answer: Eddypro software processes eddy covariance data by steps such as coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and quality control based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity. In contrast, typical hydrometeorological data processing involves averaging periods and may focus more on filtering erroneous readings due to sensor errors or environmental conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of data collected from eddy covariance systems in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collected from eddy covariance systems in arid regions are processed using Eddypro software, which includes steps like outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction. Quality evaluation is performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, and data with high missing rates or errors are excluded.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using a combination of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for understanding energy and water vapor exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Using both eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for comprehensive measurements of energy and water vapor exchanges. This combination provides a detailed understanding of these exchanges, crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, supporting sustainable development, and understanding the carbon cycle in these ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for specific data processing steps, such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction, in eddy covariance data collection methods for arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for specific data processing steps like coordinate rotation and frequency response correction arises due to the intricate nature of turbulent flux measurements in arid regions. Such corrections ensure that the data accurately reflect the natural exchanges of energy, water vapor, and carbon, accounting for potential biases introduced by instrument orientation, atmospheric conditions, and the unique characteristics of desert landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to address ecological environment degradation in inland river basins when collecting data on oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Addressing ecological environment degradation in inland river basins is critical when collecting data on oasis–desert systems because these areas face challenges like river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and land desertification. These issues impact the stability and sustainability of oasis ecosystems, which are vital for local ecological balance and economic development. Understanding these dynamics is essential for ensuring ecological security and supporting sustainable development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors drive the integration of hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters with flux data in datasets related to oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters with flux data in datasets related to oasis–desert ecosystems is driven by the need for a comprehensive understanding of the interactions within these systems. Such integration allows researchers to assess the impact of various environmental factors on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, providing insights into ecological stability, carbon cycling, and the overall functioning of oasis–desert ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data collection in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for long-term flux data collection can significantly enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This approach provides a quantitative understanding of these exchanges, which is essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development in arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the exclusion of data during instrument errors and precipitation affect the quality and reliability of the flux data collected in arid environments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding data during instrument errors and precipitation helps improve the quality and reliability of the flux data by ensuring that the datasets are not compromised by inaccurate readings. This selective data processing results in more consistent and reliable data, which is crucial for accurate analysis and modeling of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This understanding is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases and supporting the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in data collection efforts for sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is critical to achieve sustainable oasis development. It ensures the ecological security and supports sustainable development by understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems, which are vital for the ecological environment and economic foundation of arid and semi-arid areas.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques are employed to ensure the quality and reliability of eddy covariance data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing techniques include steps such as despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is conducted by assessing atmospheric stability (Δst) and turbulence similarity characteristics (ITC).

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in eddy covariance systems enable long-term monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in eddy covariance systems, such as the use of a closed-path eddy covariance system (CPEC200), allow for high-frequency data collection (10Hz) which can be processed to generate reliable half-hourly flux data. This enables the continuous monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange over long periods, providing essential data for understanding ecosystem interactions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in maintaining data quality and consistency in datasets collected from oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation problems such as drying up of rivers and lakes, land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which can complicate consistent data collection and maintenance.

Expectation.Question: What are the expectations for using long-term observational datasets in understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable to quantitatively understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be essential to include auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters in datasets related to oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters supplement the understanding of oasis–desert systems, supporting comprehensive analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges over time.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the data collection methods used for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods, utilizing eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data, combined with automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data, seem comprehensive and robust, providing a detailed understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon dynamics in arid regions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced when collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems include environmental degradation threats such as drying rivers, land desertification, and dust storms, which can complicate data collection continuity and quality.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential for expanding datasets related to oasis–desert systems in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding datasets could significantly enhance understanding of oasis–desert interactions and contribute to sustainable development goals, particularly by incorporating additional data from more regions and periods, considering the critical role these systems play in ecological stability and carbon cycling.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the various data collection methods employed in the observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange within oasis-desert ecosystems, including how data quality is ensured.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods include the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data acquisition. Hydrometeorological data are collected from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, and include parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and air pressure. Data quality is ensured through a process of data collection, processing, and archiving, which includes quality control procedures such as the removal of outliers, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, and correction for frequency response, among others.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential strategies for expanding the scope and detail of datasets capturing long-term hydrometeorological and flux data in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies include establishing additional observation stations across different arid regions to capture a wider range of data. Incorporating auxiliary data such as vegetation and soil parameters can enhance the dataset's comprehensiveness. Ensuring long-term and continuous data acquisition is crucial for capturing seasonal and interannual variations. Sharing datasets through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center can encourage collaborations and data integration across different research projects.
